# Loops in p5.js

## What are Loops?

Loops allow you to repeat code without writing it over and over again.

Instead of writing:
```javascript
circle(50, 200, 40);
circle(100, 200, 40);
circle(150, 200, 40);
circle(200, 200, 40);
circle(250, 200, 40);
```

You can use a loop to draw multiple shapes efficiently. [See comparison](https://editor.p5js.org/howshekilledit/sketches/mO1fJqkXK) 

## While Loops

A `while` loop repeats code as long as a condition is true.

``` {.javascript code-line-numbers="false"}
let x = 50;

while (x < 400) {
  circle(x, 200, 40);
  x = x + 50; 
}
```
[See it live](https://editor.p5js.org/howshekilledit/sketches/1nRY0qLmq)
<br>

**Warning:** Make sure the condition eventually becomes false, or you'll create an infinite loop!

## For Loops

A `for` loop is more structured and commonly used for counting.

``` {.javascript code-line-numbers="false"}
for (let i = 0; i < 8; i++) {
  let x = i * 50 + 50;
  circle(x, 200, 40);
}
```

**Structure** (stated several ways):<br> 
`for (initialization; condition; update) { ... }` 
<br>
`for (start state; while state; change) { ... }`
<br>
`for (<start>; <end>; <in-between-event>) { ... }`

## For Loop Breakdown

``` {.javascript code-line-numbers="false"}
for (let i = 0; i < 8; i++) {
  // code to repeat
}
```

- **`let i = 0`** - Start with i equal to 0
- **`i < 8`** - Continue while i is less than 8  
- **`i++`** - Add 1 to i after each loop
- **Result:** Loop runs 8 times (i = 0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7)

## Using the Loop Counter


``` {.javascript code-line-numbers="false"}
for (let i = 0; i < 8; i++) {
  let diameter = i * 10 + 20; 
  circle(200, 200, diameter);
}
```

This creates concentric circles. What happens when you change initial and terminating conditions?
[See it live](https://editor.p5js.org/howshekilledit/sketches/B6gUPsjnb)

## Nested Loops

You can put loops inside other loops to create grids and patterns.

``` {.javascript code-line-numbers="false"}
for (let i = 0; i < 5; i++) {        // rows
  for (let j = 0; j < 5; j++) {      // columns
    let x = j * 60 + 30;
    let y = i * 60 + 30;
    circle(x, y, 40);
  }
}
```

This creates a 5×5 grid of circles!

## How Nested Loops Work

``` {.javascript code-line-numbers="false"}
for (let i = 0; i < 3; i++) {        // Outer loop: i = 0,1,2
  for (let j = 0; j < 3; j++) {      // Inner loop: j = 0,1,2
    // This runs 9 times total!
    // (0,0) (0,1) (0,2) (1,0) (1,1) (1,2) (2,0) (2,1) (2,2)
  }
}
```

- Outer loop runs 3 times
- Inner loop runs 3 times for each outer loop
- Total: 3 × 3 = 9 repetitions
- [See it live](https://editor.p5js.org/howshekilledit/sketches/ATSpSJ_FT)

## Loops in draw()

When you put loops inside `draw()`, they run every frame:

``` {.javascript code-line-numbers="false"}
function draw() {
  background(220);
  
  for (let i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
    let x = i * 40 + 20;
    let y = mouseY;  // Follow mouse vertically
    circle(x, y, 30);
  }
}
```

This creates a row of circles that follows your mouse. [See it live](https://editor.p5js.org/howshekilledit/sketches/lmhHNX94s)

## Arrays

Arrays store multiple values in a single variable.
``` {.javascript code-line-numbers="false"}
let colors = ['red', 'green', 'blue', 'yellow'];
console.log(colors[0]); // 'red'
```

## Arrays and for loops
``` {.javascript code-line-numbers="false"}
let colors = ['red', 'green', 'blue', 'yellow'];
for (let i = 0; i < colors.length; i++) {
  fill(colors[i]);
  circle(i * 60 + 30, 200, 40);
}
```
[See it live](https://editor.p5js.org/howshekilledit/sketches/9bvhivBiY)
